args.text: The Quechua language is a family of indigenous languages spoken primarily in the Andes region of South America, including Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador, Colombia, and Chile. It is the most widely spoken pre-Columbian language family of the Americas, with an estimated 8-10 million speakers as of 2004. Quechua was the main language family of the Inca Empire and is still widely spoken today, being the co-official language of many regions and the second most spoken language family in Peru. The language has been recognized as an official language in Peru, Ecuador, and Bolivia.
